message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about the physical properties of steam and ice. Both steam and ice are made up of the same substance, water, in different states of matter. They both have intensive properties, which means their properties do not depend on the amount of substance present. Options (B), (C), and (D) are incorrect because although steam and ice have different forms, temperatures, and appearances, these properties are not what they have in common.

This question requires knowledge about the physical properties of steam and ice. Both steam and ice are forms of water, and water has intensive properties such as density, color, and boiling point that are independent of the amount of substance present. Therefore, option (A) is correct. Option (B) is incorrect because although steam and ice have different forms, they are both still considered as water. Option (C) is incorrect because steam and ice can have different temperatures depending on whether they are heated or cooled. Option (D) is incorrect because steam and ice can have different appearances - steam is gaseous while ice is solid.

This question requires knowledge about the physical properties of steam and ice. Both steam and ice are forms of water and therefore have the same intensive properties. Option (B) is incorrect because form refers to the physical state (solid, liquid, or gas) rather than a property they have in common. Option (C) is also incorrect because steam and ice can have different temperatures. Option (D) is not true because steam and ice have different appearances - steam is a gas while ice is a solid.

This question requires knowledge of the properties of steam and ice. Both steam and ice are forms of water, and therefore have the same molecular composition. They can both undergo changes in state (from solid to liquid or from liquid to gas) depending on temperature and pressure. These changes in state are physical changes and do not alter the composition of the substance. Therefore, both steam and ice have the same intensive properties, such as density, boiling point, and melting point. Option (B) is incorrect because although they have different forms, they can both exist as solid or gas depending on the conditions. Option (C) is incorrect because steam and ice can exist at different temperatures depending on the pressure. Option (D) is incorrect because the appearance of steam and ice are different - steam is a gas and ice is a solid.

Option (B) is incorrect because while steam and ice have different forms, they are still both water. Option (C) is incorrect because steam and ice can have different temperatures. Option (D) is incorrect because steam and ice have different appearances - steam is invisible vapor, while ice is solid and visible. Only option (A) is true because both steam and ice have intensive properties that are characteristic of water, such as density and specific heat capacity.
